Award.AwardTitle: Enhancement of Cyber Connectivity within the Nevada System of Higher Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Proposal Number: EPS-1006797

Proposal Title: Enhancement of Cyber Connectivity within the Nevada System of Higher Education

Institution: Nevada System of Higher Education

This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

The goal of this EPSCoR Research Infrastructure Improvement Inter-Campus and Intra-Campus Cyber Connectivity project is to enhance connectivity within the Nevada System of Higher Education to achieve higher network speeds and capacity to advance education and research in Nevada. The mechanism for improved connectivity is equipment upgrades for six existing nodes on the Las Vegas metro fiber loop.

Intellectual Merit
The capacity improvements will provide scientists and engineers with the network resources to further build expertise in computational science, a recognized major component of the scientific enterprise. Enhanced connectivity to research universities, community and state colleges, field stations, and other academic and public entities will have broad-ranging impact on research and education enterprises throughout Nevada. Institutions will be linked to more than 200 other Internet2 universities, government research laboratories, companies, and research facilities throughout the world, facilitating data-intensive research, collaborative development, distributed experiments, grid-based data analysis, and experimentation using high performance networking, social networking, and cyber-enabled learning.

Broader Impacts
The award will enable Nevada to make major improvements to NevadaNet, which provides connectivity to remote areas, rural centers, small colleges and regional universities, Native American tribes and peoples, and persons with disabilities. The enhanced connectivity will connect universities with K-12 schools as well as provide for economic development and other opportunities that can result from high-bandwidth access (e.g., distance education, tele-health instruction and support, and sharing of economic and community development materials). The proposed educational programs in high performance computing will provide students, postdoctoral associates, and faculty training in computational tools that will broaden participation in, and understanding of, computational thinking and modeling in general, and climate change science in particular, and foster the next generation of cyber-literate scientists and engineers working to solve climate change and other societal problems.

Intellectual Merit

The goal of Nevada’s C2 project was to enhance connectivity within the Nevada System of Higher Education (NSHE) to achieve higher network speeds and capacity to advance education and research. The goal was attained with cyberinfrastructure (CI) improvements that enhanced intra- and inter-institutional communications, collaboration, and research capability by providing increased operating flexibility and up to 160 times the network capacity of the previous system. These new capabilities have provided NSHE STEM scientists with the network resources to further build expertise in computational science, which together with theory and experimentation, now constitutes what is widely called the “third pillar” of the scientific enterprise. Enhanced connectivity to research universities, community and state colleges, field stations, and other academic and public entities are having broad-ranging impact on research and education enterprises throughout Nevada. The connectivity improvements have significantly increased linkage of NSHE institutions to other Internet2 universities, government research laboratories, companies, and many research facilities throughout the world, facilitating data-intensive research, collaborative development, distributed experiments, grid-based data analysis, and experimentation using high performance networking, social networking, and cyber-enabled learning. Most importantly, combined improvements in connectivity in concert with training opportunities in high performance computing have positioned Nevada to advance to the forefront of computational science.

 

Broader Impacts

The CI investments have achieved broad impact and added value by leveraging existing resources and infrastructure within Nevada. The C2 funds enabled major improvements to NevadaNet, which provides connectivity to remote areas, rural centers, small colleges and regional universities, Native American tribes and peoples, and persons with disabilities in the nation’s evolving cyber-enabled social and educational structures. This positions Nevada to connect K–12 schools as well as provide for economic development and other opportunities that can result from high-bandwidth access (e.g., distance STEM education, tele-health instruction and support, and sharing of economic and community development materials). In addition, the new cyberinfrastructure has provided a gateway to rural network health programs through the University of Nevada School of Medicine (UNSOM) and the ongoing mission of Cooperative Extension programs throughout the State.  A primary objective of the project was to engage and train the workforce on how to utilize the higher network speeds and new technology, which is essential for realizing the full potential of cyberinfrastructure improvements in Nevada. Ultimately, the C2 improvements are fostering the next generation of CI-literate scientists and engineers to be able to solve climate change and other societal problems.  Specific educational and workforce development activities funded by the C2 award included three high impact accomplishments:
